For a solar oven to properly work, it needs insulation to hold in any heat that builds up inside it, and the mirrored surfaces have to be as smooth as you can make them so all the light reflects INTO the oven. Your crumpled aluminum foil had pretty much no chance of working properly. I made a solar oven for a science project in high school and we cooked a hot dog in it and dried some apples, both of which worked beautifully. We achieved temperatures of 350ish degrees. Not QUITE hot enough for a pizza, but if I'd used real mirrors instead of aluminum foil, I'm betting we could have gotten a lot higher. You should try making a decent one. :)

Pair of solar scorchers. one beam bounces off a mirror to heat the bottom of the pan (not pinpoint... you want to heat it, not melt it), and the other just goes directly into the pan to heat the top.
also, use an actual pizza. This means a ratio of ~1:3 for crust thickness to topping thickness. not 1:64 like yall had.

Place oven inside a car with window directly facing the sun and no air. Car traps heat and with the tinfoil and etc, your solar oven gets improved. I did this once to cook chocolate chip cookies. It was delicious but also very cookie smelly in car lol.

If you have completely raw dough covered in toppings, you will never get a proper crispy pizza. The 2 tricks to a crispy pizza are 1) preheat your cooking surface (something like a stone or cast iron pan that holds heat well) and 2) precook the dough about halfway before adding sauce, cheese, or any toppings. That's how we do it in New York

I did something similar when I was younger with a solar oven. I didn’t make a solar oven per say but I had this plastic Tupperware container filled with pasta and cheese (the pasta was cold and cheese wasn’t melted) so me being the smart 8-10 year old I was at the time I put the tin foil I had and put it over my cold pasta and cheese and set it in direct sunlight. (I was at the pool with a summer camp so I wasn’t able to heat up my food) funnily enough my pasta became decently warm and my cheese melted very well. I was a very proud kid that day

The pizza needs to be heated top and bottom at the same time.
You neen a much larger box lined with Al foil and the pizza needs to be on a pan several inches above the box bottom so reflected light hits the bottom of the pan.
A dark domed lid over the pizza would catch the incoming light and warm the pizza from above. The lid edge needs to be in contact with the pizza pan to form an oven. Think Dutch oven.
Look up a wood stove pizza cooker.

I built a solar oven for smores in 5th grade science class. I used foil tape in the shoebox so the light wouldn't be refracted as much as long with a black coffee lid for the plate/ heat absorber. We use a very bright light instead of the sun. But it took mine maybe 5 or 6 minutes to fully melt chocolate and started to melt the marshmallow.

Pineapple on pizza is a fine thing.  The problem comes when you put a tomato-ey maranara with pineapple.  There's a pizza chain called "Pizza Shuttle" (whose restaurants are no longer affiliated with each other) that I grew up with in KS (There's one each in Manhattan and Lawrence, as well as a few in Norman OK, so it's a college-town business).  Pizza Shuttle offers cream cheese as an alternate sauce.  And hawiian pizza with cream cheese is WAY BETTER than with maranara.

I prefer my pizza crispy but not burnt why not try cooking a pizza on a pizza stone in your grill that’s what I do but don’t walk away from it you constantly have to check it to make sure it’s not burning on the bottom and there’s no fixed time for how long The pizza should stay in the grill it depends on your grill The optimum temperature I found is 500 to Preheat the grill  and the stone And don’t forget to oil the pizza stone with whatever oil of your choice once Grill is up to 500 lThen turn all the burners to low And let the temp drop to 475 then put the pizza on the pizza stone And regulate the burners to keep the temp at 475  Or near as close as or you can just experiment with the temp  there’s no fixed time for how long the pizzas cook I go by what the bottom looks like and the top looks like. Oil the pizza stone before you put it on the grill canola oil vegetable oil whatever you use
